quoteLast: . We came back to the same room where all that remained of her was a pool of blood. We became terribly depressed as if we had behaved badly toward her to give her up without a fight.
title: The Red Reign: The True Story of an Adventurous Year in Russia
author: Durland, Kellogg, 1881-1911

quoteFirst: Leaving Tompkinsville at three o'clock in the afternoon, after paroling the prisoners, we reached Glasgow
quoteLast: . This town was unoccupied by any garrison, and its people were very friendly to us. Company C, of the old squadron had been principally recruited here. The command rested at Glasgow until 9 A.M. next day; during the time, the ladies busied themselves in preparing breakfast for us, and before we left, every man had taken in a three days' supply.
title: History of Morgan's Cavalry
author: Duke, Basil Wilson, 1838-1916

quoteFirst: It being late in the evening of April 8, 1864, when I reported on board the United States steamer Minnesota, and there being no opportunity to return ashore, I was compelled to remain aboard the Minnesota till the following morning, April 9, 1864. Being very much fatigued, I retired early, and soon fell soundly asleep.
quoteLast: , I was aroused from my slumbers by a noise; I could not for the life of me tell from whence it came or whither it had gone; but it was sufficient to arouse and bewilder me, for it made the vessel tremble. I soon arose from my sleeping couch, put on my clothes, and made my way, in the darkness, through the ward-room to the forward hatchway, and to the gun deck.
title: Reminiscences of Two Years in the United States Navy
author: Batten, John M. (John Mullin), 1837-1916

quoteFirst: The heat was oppressive; clouds of dust filled the atmosphere, and almost choked the unfortunate victims exposed to its irritating influence; provisions were painfully scarce, and Colonel Weimam absolutely refused to sell or give a grain of barley to the traveller’s starving horses.  At last,
quoteLast: on the 14th of May, the Russian detachment marched out of camp, and struck to the westward, in the direction of Adam-Kurulgan and the Amu-Daria.  Mr. MacGahan and his men were on the alert.
title:
Some Heroes of Travel
or, Chapters from the History of Geographical Discovery and Enterprise
author: Adams, W. H. Davenport (William Henry Davenport), 1828-1891

quoteLast: the two gaffs with which Bernard had contrived to shore up the slowly heeling yacht began to show signs of yielding, and, in approved shipwreck fashion, we took to the boats, the yacht's crew in the gig remaining in attendance on what seemed likely to be the last moments of the _Eileen Oge_, while we, in the dinghy, sought for the harbour.
title: Some Experiences of an Irish R.M.
author: Somerville, E. Oe. (Edith Oenone), 1858-1949; Ross, Martin, 1862-1915

quoteFirst: The heat was oppressive; clouds of dust filled the atmosphere, and almost choked the unfortunate victims exposed to its irritating influence; provisions were painfully scarce, and Colonel Weimam absolutely refused to sell or give a grain of barley to the traveller’s starving horses. quoteLast: on the 14th of May, the Russian detachment marched out of camp, and struck to the westward, in the direction of Adam-Kurulgan and the Amu-Daria.  Mr. MacGahan and his men were on the alert.

quoteFirst: The country in a sense was dangerous, because the neighbouring watering-point called Agaragar, has often proved to be the favourite camping-ground for raiders entering Air from the north. It happened while I was taking an astronomical observation during the night at
quoteLast: that a sudden wind arose in the valley, and the camp woke up with a sense of foreboding. The air seemed filled with impending danger, of which the camels also became aware.
title: People of the veil
author: Rennell of Rodd, Francis James Rennell Rodd, Baron, 1895-1978

quoteLast: Oh, the sadness and gloom at our mess that night! Few words were spoken. Some of us hoped against hope. We earnestly cherished the hope that Major Scobell would find some way out of this gorge of death. At 5.30 we were up and ready to march.
title:
South Africa and the Transvaal War, Vol. 6 (of 8)
From the Occupation of Pretoria to Mr. Kruger's Departure from South Africa, with a Summarised Account of the Guerilla War to March 1901
author: Creswicke, Louis

quoteLast: of May 5, Gen. Hooker telegraphed me to cross the river, and take up the bridges. This is the despatch: 'Despatch this moment received. Withdraw; cover the river, and prevent any force crossing.
title: The Campaign of Chancellorsville
author: Dodge, Theodore Ayrault, 1842-1909

quoteFirst: There are two settees, L. and R. On the table L. writing material. It is
title: The Devil
author: Molnár, Ferenc, 1878-1952; Herford, Oliver, 1863-1935 [Adapter]

quoteFirst: 555); Apuntes, 376; =76=Horn, Nov. 15, 21; Gaxiola, Invasión, 186. A land party of 94 and a boat party of 62 set out from Mazatlán at
quoteLast: The Mexicans, who were commanded by Lieut. Carlos Horn, a Swiss, ought to have been routed, but they had received notice of the expedition and were on the alert. The American land party fell partially into an ambuscade, and the boat party were misled.
title: The War with Mexico, Volume 2 (of 2)
author: Smith, Justin Harvey, 1857-1930

quoteLast: Caleb Morton reached the cottage breathless with running, and before a word was spoken between them, Anastasia had fallen on his shoulder and had fainted. As soon as she was in the arms of her lover, all her power had gone from her.
title: Tales of All Countries
author: Trollope, Anthony, 1815-1882

quoteLast: I was awakened by hearing someone climbing over the tail-board. Responding to my challenge the Cockney said: "It's all right. The blighter's been and pinched my blanket and greatcoat.
title: 500 of the Best Cockney War Stories
author: Various; Hamilton, Ian, 1853-1947 [Contributor]; Thomas, Bert, 1883-1966 [Illustrator]

quoteFirst: A steeple rises above the church of the castle, which I, however, did not ascend, being fatigued, and the steps in a neglected state. We rode back to Marazion, which was formerly called Marketzew, and has eleven hundred inhabitants, and passing by Helstone, we arrived
quoteLast: , much fatigued, at Falmouth. Penryn, to which I made several excursions, contains a row of newly-built, elegant houses, with handsome gardens and a catholic church. The beautiful terrace on which the new houses stand with their gardens, is called the Green Bank, and is a very agreeable promenade.
title: Travels Through North America, During the Years 1825 and 1826. v. 1-2
author: Bernhard, Duke of Saxe-Weimar-Eisenach, 1792-1862

quoteFirst: The half-dozen doubters who awaited his advent in the Broadway were surprised
quoteLast: to see him running as fast as he could put legs to the ground, with only the remnant of a shirt on him; after recovering his breath and his courage he proceeded to describe the terrific slaughter he had inflicted on an innumerable number of assailants.  A scurrilous print that flourished about this time in its next issue narrated the incident in verse by: “Oh, pray for the souls that Corrigan kilt,” etc.
title: London in the Sixties (with a few digressions)
author: Shaw, Donald [Dubious author]; Widmington, Ernest [Dubious author]

quoteFirst: The conspiracy was dramatically carried out. On the 21st of February, 1824,
quoteLast: , a violent knocking was heard at the door of the "Ship Inn," then the principal hotel of Dover. On the door being opened, a person in richly embroidered scarlet uniform, wet with spray, announced himself as Lieutenant-Colonel De Bourg, aide-de-camp of Lord Cathcart.
title:
Old and New London, Volume I
A Narrative of Its History, Its People, and Its Places
author: Thornbury, Walter, 1828-1876

quoteFirst: It was only later on that I learned the success of this mission. The two spies arrived on a certain night at
quoteLast: and did their part so well that, by two a.m., the terrified Khan had mounted his camel, and set forth for Makran.
title:
Raiders of the Sarhad
Being an Account of the Campaign of Arms and Bluff Against the Brigands of the Persian-Baluchi Border during the Great War
author: Dyer, R. E. H. (Reginald Edward Harry), 1864-1927

quoteLast: three clear, sharp cries of an owl, wonderfully well imitated, echoed through the square. Pierrette heard them in her feverish sleep; she jumped up, moist with perspiration, opened her window, saw Brigaut, and flung down a ball of silk, to which he fastened a letter.
title: Pierrette
author: Balzac, Honoré de, 1799-1850; Wormeley, Katharine Prescott, 1830-1908 [Translator]

quoteFirst: The next morning I struck out again hunting work, but this time on an empty stomach. About two o'clock in the afternoon I found a hack driver who said he wanted to hire a boy to take care of his horses; he said he would not be going home until
quoteLast: and for me to wait for him in front of the Court house on Fourth street.
title:
A Texas Cow Boy
or, fifteen years on the hurricane deck of a Spanish pony, taken from real life
author: Siringo, Charles A., 1855-1928
